title: For Sale:  Original Civil War 1861 Springfield, Watertown Contract,
postcontent:
This Civil War musket is a fine piece of documented history.  Everything works.  It has the original bayonet and what might be a non-original ram rod that appears to be the same vintage.  This gun has not been modified or touched in any way.  I'm sure it will clean up and be a beautiful addition to any history buff's collection.  I have many more pictures that I will email upon request.

U.S. RIFLE-MUSKET MODEL 1861 CONTRACT (HOARD) PERCUSSION .58 CAL.
Manufactured by Charles B. Hoard, Watertown, N.Y. in 1863 - Standard Model 1861 single-shot muzzle loading rifle-musket. Three bands, spring fastened. Iron furniture, finished patina. Double leaf rear sight. Weapon weighs approximately 9 lbs. Charles Hoard manufactured about 12,800 contracts.

Markings:
Lock: 1863 behind hammer. Eagle. U.S./WATERTOWN forward of hammer. 
Barrel: 1863. V/P/Eaglehead.  
Bands: U.
Hammer: B.
Triggerguard: B.
Buttplate: US.

Notes: Charles B. Hoard of Watertown, New York had been the manufacturer of steam engines before the Civil War, and owned and operated a modern, well-equipped factory in that city.
On December 24, 1861, Hoard received his first of two contracts for Model 1861 rifle-muskets, calling for 50,000 at $20.00 each. This was followed on December 1, 1863 with the second contract specifying 20,000 stands at $19.00 each.
Under the first of these, Hoard was able to produce only 1,500 arms, these being delivered between September 17 and November 30, 1863. By August 2, 1865, an additional 11,300, produced under the second contract, had been delivered, bringing the total to 12,800. All were typical Model 1861 rifle-muskets....
With the exception of a few parts purchased elsewhere early in production, the entire arm was fabricated and assembled in the Hoard Armory at Watertown. It was also at this location that the small number of .44 caliber Freeman Army revolvers were turned out." - Reilly

"...In support of the price of the guns, $20, upon which he calculated to make less than his usual 10% profit on steam engines, Hoard offered an unusual calculation of the cost of the Government made article. This cost basis is the one any private enterprise must go by, figuring in all overhead before deriving a total cost of the gun. But the Springfield accountants work on the governmental philosophy that if you have a government, you gotta have an armory also. Their computations of the cost of a musket therefore leave out entirely the enormous capital investment at the National Armory, and figure a lot of bare costs without full overhead put in. The calculation Hoard's way was rather stiff: 'Supposed cost of Springfield Armory buildings and machinery: 2,000,000. Annual average production, 14,000 arms. Upon this data, as a basis, and I believe it is very near the truth, it would appear that the annual interest at 6% on the cost is: $120,000.
Assuming that the machinery cost one-half of the outlay, which is not far from the fact, and that the natural wear and loss of machinery is ten percent, and when work is prosecuted only during the day, and this is the rate usually calculated upon by manufacturers, and double that when night and day work is performed, the loss on one million of dollars annually is $100,000.
The cost for present production of a musket is $14 each, which would be for 140,000 muskets. The total here is $196,000.
Showing the actual cost to the government, upon this calculation, believe to be even below the truth, to be $29.17.'
But Hoard's senatorial friends, his calculations to show the economy of doing business with Hoard's Armory, his letters, even personally laying the matter before Abraham Lincoln, availed him nothing but the conclusions above cited." - Edwards

References:
Edwards, William B. CIVIL WAR GUNS. Castle. Secaucus, N.J. 1982.
Flayderman, Norm. FLAYDERMAN'S GUIDE TO ANTIQUE AMERICAN FIREARMS...AND THEIR VALUES. 6th Ed. DBI Books, Inc. Northbrook, Il. 1994.
Reilly, Robert. U.S. MILITARY SMALL ARMS 1816-1865. The Eagle Press. Baton Rouge, La. 1970.


Summary of Provenance, with records. 

•	Samuel T. Hauser Sr. born January 10, 1833 in Falmouth, Kentucky was the original Owner.
•	STH Sr. acquired 1861 Springfield musket.
•	STH Sr. was the 7th Governor of Montana Territory, appointed by President Cleveland.
•	STH Sr. died November 10, 1914.
•	Son Samuel T. Hauser Jr., his son, was born in 1879.
•	STR Jr. inherited the 1861 musket after STH Sr’s. death. 
•	STH Jr. lived at 909 Flowerree Street as shown on 1940 US Federal census.
•	Subsequent purchaser of 909 Flowerree St. Helena, Montana, where STH Jr. lived, found the 1861 Springfield musket behind the coal bin during renovation of the property.  Provenance was established through Federal census information and real estate ownership documentation combined with the “H” carved in the stock.  The person that found the musket is Carl Sharen.  He is still alive and living in Florida. 
•	The 1861 Springfield musket was kept in the Sharen family that renovated 909 Flowerree Street Helena, Montana until 2014 when Steven Bruce acquired it.  It was part of a transaction.
•	I am Steven Bruce’s Father, David Bruce.  He has asked me to sell it.

This was a rare model made by Smith and Wesson, and was arguably discontinued due to it's expense to build. They used a Titanium cylinder which gave the ability to tighten the tolerance between cylinder chambers so as to achieve the 7th round without increasing the size or mass of the cylinder. They also utilized a two piece barrel construction with the steel outer sleeve housing a stainless screw in barrel insert. This was pioneered by Dan Wesson revolvers and is renown for controlling the tolerance between the cylinder face and the barrel forcing cone.
